> > OTS subtransactions are very different from top-level transactions.

> As i've dived into several specification documents
> (not comments about them), i've discovered that OTS doesn't support 
> directly nested transaction but only subtransaction (as you said). And
JTS 
> is based upon OTS. So it explains the "nested transactions not
required".
> About EJB 2.0 spec, it is written : "no nested transactions supported". 
> Authors explain that they want EJB spec to be implemented on any
database
> system. They add that EJB spec could support nested transactions if 
> databases support them...

Actually, in the terminology of transaction services, nested transactions
*are* subtransactions.  What was being discussed earlier was a way to have
resources commit (that is, visible) for testing purposes but still have
them uncommit in the end.  This is really an issue of transaction
isolation, which determines who is allowed to see changes at different
stages in the lifetime of a transaction.  Isolation is an
implementation-specific characteristic.  Perhaps if you check your
database docs, you can find an isolation level that will allow you to test
the way you were hoping.  It won't be portable, but it could work.

The reason OTS does not require nested/sub- transactions is because it was
designed by a committee of transaction manager (database) vendors and most
databases do not support nested/sub- transactions.  Committee specs tend
to be all-inclusive because they have to have broad support to be adopted
(which, for example, is why the conference in Durban is having problems,
but that is definitely way off-topic).

If you really want to see a hole in the EJB spec, check out the optional
interposit coordinator implementation suggested by OTS.  I developed a
transaction manager that used interposits which was later used by our EJB
container.  The practical result is this:  do not make transactional
remote calls during the beforeCompletion() call in a Synchronization.  The
state of a transaction is local, not global, and resources registered at
one node can be polled before synchronizations' beforeCompletion() are
called in another node.

The EJB spec, of course, makes no mention of this situation.  On the plus
side, I have not seen another implementation that uses the suggested
interposit implementation, so my warning can be largely ignored.

-Steve  :)
